results.title: The Discovery of television
results.creator_credit: John Lloyd, Alasdair Milne, BBC-TV and JBM Productions
results.brief_description: The discovery and development of television is not the story of the efforts of a single person, but of many people. It is a search through a tangled web of scientific discoveries, inventions, and developments, of ideas tried and rejected and tried again, culminating with the efforts of an enthusiastic team of professionals led by Sir Isaac Shoenberg. Describes the early experiments in television leading to the first regular broadcasts from London beginning on 2nd November 1936. The work of the pioneers is reconstructed using contemporary records and interviews.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Lloyd, Alasdair Milne, BBC-TV and JBM Productions

results.title: The Discovery of radium
results.creator_credit: Bernard Girard, James Fonda and CBS TV America
results.brief_description: Henri Becquerel a French scientist while studying uranium discovers properties hitherto unknown to the scientific world. The substance emitted rays that could penetrate black paper and leave an impression on a sensitive photographic plate. Pierre Curie and his wife Marie discover the unknown element, radio-active radium. The significance of their discovery was realised and the novelist Jules Verne considers that the possible results of the Curie’s work could be fantastic. He remarks that it is God’s glory to make a secret of things - man’s glory to uncover them. Presented by Walter Cronkite.

results.title: Discovery - penicillin
results.creator_credit: Dennis Rich and British Information Services
results.brief_description: An outline history of the discovery of penicillin by Sir Alexander Fleming and its development as a human drug by Sir Howard Florey and Dr E.B. Chain. Uses archival footage and animated graphics.

results.title: Grass
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Discovery”.
Australian scientists are looking at how the use of marijuana affects the mind and body of the user. Researchers and users are shown here examining what happens to a person who is under the influence of marijuana. They investigate the claims that are often made about this drug - that marijuana leads to the use of hard drugs. Marijuana is now illegal in most countries, but the marijuana explosion of the 60s and 70s has led to a growing campaign supporting legislation.

results.title: Aurora
results.creator_credit: Peter Jones, David Taylor and Yorkshire Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Discovery”.
An investigation of the mystery surrounding the Aurora Borealis. An Australian physicist, Dr Robert Eather, at Boston College, Massachusetts has developed a method of filming the aurora in color.

results.title: An Eye for the job
results.creator_credit: Nigel Miller, Kevin Sim and Yorkshire Television
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Discovery”.
A documentary about the quiet revolution in the operating theatre. The surgeon has now harnessed his skills to the microscope, and operations of the most minute detail are achieved with microsurgery. Depicts five case studies - a blind painter is made to see again, a deaf grandmother can hear again, a worker’s torn off hand is restored, a man’s severed thumb is replaced by his big toe, and a young woman has her fallopian tubes untied.

results.title: Discovering the world
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Children Thinking”.
First of four studies of the development of thinking in children from five to ten. Shows how their drawing and painting expresses understanding of their environment and traces its development.

results.title: Discovering mood in music (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Through listening to various types of music the class discovers different ways that the composer has used to depict moods. Then they find that they can move in ways that reflect the moods of music and art.

results.title: Discovering melody and harmony (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Illustrates the movement and relationship of melody and harmony in music. Harmony is added to the melody through the use of descant and thirds and by playing instruments showing how both can move in repeats, steps or skips.

results.title: Discovering jazz (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Traces the history of jazz from its roots in nineteenth century black America. Rhythmic and melodic freedom were added to the harmony and structure of European music, and techniques like note bending, call and response were added. Jazz soon became popular and its form progressed from dixie and blues through such styles as swing, bop, cool jazz, funky and free improvisation.
